children.name: made to look real for dishonest purposes
forgery
children.definition: an illegal copy of sth official such as a bank note, legal documentation or work of art: đồ giả , giấy tờ giả
examples: The painting, believed to be by Renoir, turned out to be a very clever forgery.
Three paintings now thought to be forgeries are included in the show
Further investigation showed that the so-called ‘Hitler Diaries’ were a forgery.
forged[adj] a forged official document or bank note has been illegally made to look like a real one: (tài liệu, giấy bạc) giả
He came into the country using a forged visa.
a forged £50 note.

children.name: dummy
children.definition: a dummy object is one that is made to look like the real object but cannot be used: giả (không dùng được)
examples: dummy rifles súng giả
Semionov threatened the pilot with a dummy hand grenade and forced him to land the plane.

children.name: false
children.definition: not real, but made to look real in order to deceive people: giả
examples: He gave the clerk a false name and address in case the police were looking for him.
Her suitcase had a false bottom, containing 2 kilos of heroin.
She was charged with giving falseevidencein court.
When she was stopped by the police for speeding, she gave them a falsenameand address.He assumed a falseidentity(= pretended he was someone else) in order to escape from the police.

children.name: counterfeit
children.definition: counterfeit money looks exactly like real money but has been produced illegally: giả (tiền)
examples: Police have warned stores to look out for counterfeit $50 bills.

children.name: fraud
children.definition: sth that is not what it is claimed to be : vật giả mạo
examples: I felt like a fraud.
The police exposed the letter as a fraud.

children.name: fake
children.definition: use this about objects or documents that are not real, but are intended to look like sth more important or valuable: giả
examples: They were selling fake Rolex watches on the market stall.
a fake driver’s license
Whitehorn pleaded guilty to possession of equipment to make fake identification documents.
They were selling fake Rolex watches on the street.
fake[C noun] [C2] a copy of a valuable object or painting that is intended to deceive people: đồ giả
Three months after I bought it, a friend who works at the museum told me it was probably a fake.
Is the vase a genuine antique or a fake?
fake[T verb] [C2] to make an object look real or valuable in order to deceive people : làm giả
to fake a document/ signature.

children.name: pirate
children.definition: /pirated
examples: pirate copies/ videos/ CDscopies of books, records, films etc that have been made illegally and are sold without the permission of the people who originally produced them: lậu , giả
The government has closed a factory that was producing pirate CDs.
It’s pretty easy to get pirated copies of the software.

children.name: phoney
children.definition: / phony informal sth that is phoney is false, but usually in an obvious way so that people realize it is not real: giả (rõ ràng)
examples: I left a phoney name but the right telephone number.
Ever since he came back from London, John’s been talking with a phony British accent.

children.name: act
children.definition: insincere behaviour in which you pretend to have a particular kind of feeling or to be a particular kind of person : diễn
examples: Was she really upset or was that just an act?
Mike played the loving husband in front of the children but it was all an act.
Be natural. Don’t feel you have toput on an act.

children.name: pretend
children.definition: to behave as though sth is true when you know that it is not: giả vờ
examples: We thought that he was really hurt, but he was just pretending.
pretend (that)
Bill closed his eyes, and pretended that the war was over and that he was safe at home.
pretend to do sth
I pretended not to see her, and carried on walking down the street.
pretend to be happy/ ill/ angry etc
She pretended to be ill and took a day off work

children.name: be putting it on
children.definition: to pretend to be ill, upset, injured etc,because you want to avoid doing sth or you want people to feel sorry for you: khoác cái vẻ, làm ra vẻ, làm ra bộ
examples: I don’t think she’s really ill - she’s just putting it on because she doesn’t want to go to school.
I couldn’t tell if Harvey was putting it on, or if he really was upset.
I can't tell whether he's really upset, or if he's just puttingiton.

children.name: make out
children.definition: sth informal to pretend that a situation exists in order to deceive sb: giả bộ
examples: make out (that)
We managed to fool the ticket collector by making out we couldn’t speak English.
Two days later Joyce phoned to ask about the check, so I had to make out I’d already mailed it.
He made out (that) he had been living in Paris all year.
make sth out to be
They made it out to be a really interesting job, but in fact it was ridiculously boring.
The British weather is not always as bad as it is made out to be .

children.name: be faking it
children.definition: informal to pretend to be interested, ill etc, when you are not: đang giả bộ
examples: The kid is always saying he’s too sick to go to school, and his parents figure he’s faking it.
I look at all the faces around me. Are these people really that happy? Or are they just faking it like I am?
fake[I or T verb] to pretend that you have a feeling or illness : giả bộ
to fake surprise
to fake an orgasm
She didn't want to go out, so she faked a headache.
He faked a heart attack and persuaded prison staff to take him to hospital.
He isn't really crying, he's just faking.

children.name: live a lie
children.definition: to pretend all the time that you feel or believe sth that you do not feel or believe: sống giả dối
examples: I had to leave him - I couldn’t go on living a lie.
She doesn't know you're married? You have to stop living a lie and tell her.

children.name: go through the motions
children.definition: (of doing sth) to do sth because you have to do it, without being very interested in it : làm cho có
examples: I feel so bored at work, like I’m just going through the motions.
He says he's been investigating my complaint, but I feel he's just going through the motions.

children.name: keep up appearances
children.definition: to pretend that everything in your life is still as happy and successful as it used to be, even though you have suffered some kind of trouble or loss : giữ thể diện
examples: Of course, he tries to keep up appearances, but he lives entirely off borrowed money.
She put Christmas decorations in the window just to keep up appearances.
They were very unhappily married but kept up appearances for the sake of their children.

children.name: in disguise
children.definition: made to seem like sth else that is better : trá hình
examples: ‘Tax reform’ is just a tax increase in disguise.
He claims that most Western aid to the Third World is just colonialism in disguise.

children.name: impersonate
children.definition: to behave as though you are sb with official power or sb famous, either for dishonest reasons or in order to entertain people: đóng giả
examples: I got home to find him impersonating Elvis Presley in front of the mirror.
It’s illegal to impersonate a police officer.

children.name: pretend
children.definition: to behave as if you are sb else and try to make other people believe this: giả vờ
examples: pretend to be sb
We pretended to be students and got into the club for free.
pretend (that)
They got into the house by pretending they worked for the electricity company.

children.name: do an impersonation
children.definition: / do an impression to speak, walk, or behave like someone else, in order to make people laugh: đóng giả
examples: do an impersonation/do an impression of
Stuart did a brilliant impersonation of the boss.
a comedian with his own TV show, who does impressions of famous politicians

children.name: role play
children.definition: when you pretend to be sb else and behave as they would behave, especially as a way of learning about a situation or developing a skill: đóng vai
examples: The course uses role play to teach you how to deal with difficult or aggressive customers.

children.name: make yourself out to be
children.definition: to pretend that you are cleverer, richer, more important etc than you really are:
examples: He made himself out to be a millionaire.
Richard led us around the art gallery, making himself out to be some kind of expert on modern art.
What I don’t like about her is that she makes herself out to be something special.

children.name: pose as
children.definition: to pretend to be sb else, especially sb in an official position, in order to make it easier for you to do sth bad or illegal: giả mạo là
examples: He posed as a doctor to gain access to the hospital.
There have been cases of thieves posing as telephone engineers to trick people into letting them into their homes.
He's posingasher date, but he's really her bodyguard.

children.name: masquerade as
children.definition: to pretend that you are sb else, especially by dressing or behaving in the way that they do - used especially in literature and stories: hóa trang như
examples: He got into the stadium masquerading as a security guard.
A journalist masquerading as a businessman approached the politicians, and offered them bribes.
Hooligans masquerading as football fans have once again caused disturbances.

children.name: disguise as
children.definition: to change your appearance, especially your clothes, so that you look like sb else and people cannot recognize you : cải trang như
examples: He escaped across the border disguised as a priest.
disguise yourself as
Maybe you could disguise yourself as a waiter and sneak in there.

children.name: in disguise
children.definition: wearing a disguise : cải trang
examples: She usually goes out in disguise to avoid being bothered by the public.
The woman in the park turned out to be a police officer in disguise.

children.name: falsify
children.definition: to dishonestly change official documents or records so that they contain false information: xuyên tạc, làm giả (tài liệu)
examples: She falsified her birth certificate to get the job.
A whole team was kept busy falsifying official government records.
Their accounts had been falsified over a long period of time

children.name: sb who pretends to be sb else
impostor
children.definition: /imposter  sb who pretends to be sb else in order to deceive people and gain sth such as money or power: kẻ mạo danh
examples: It was not the real Dr Frazer but an impostor.
The man registered at a Las Vegas hotel as Dustin Hoffman, and it wasn’t until he left without paying his bill that people realized he was an impostor.
He felt like an impostor among all those intelligent people, as if he had no right to be there.

children.name: charlatan
children.definition: sb who pretends to have special skills or knowledge, for example as a doctor or teacher, when in fact they do not: lang băm
examples: Some psychic charlatan convinced her she was going to die in six months.
Charlatans advertise a variety of fat-reducing treatments in the back of magazines.
No. She isn’t a miracle worker. She isn’t even a doctor. She’s a complete charlatan.
Some people said that he was one of the greatest philosophers who ever lived; others claimed he was a charlatan.

children.name: bogus
children.definition: pretending to have a particular job or position that you do not have, in order to do sth dishonest or illegal: ma, không có thật, giả
examples: The government has announced tough new measures to deal with bogus asylum-seekers.
bogus official/ social worker/ policeman etc
The child was taken away from her parents by a bogus social worker.
There has been a spate of incidents where bogus officials have called on the homes of elderly people.

children.name: fake
children.definition: sb who is not what they claim to be or does not have the skills they say they have : kẻ giả mạo
examples: After working for ten years as a doctor, he was exposed as a fake.
Her psychologist turned out to be a fake.

children.name: fraud
children.definition: sb that is not what it is claimed to be : kẻ giả mạo
examples: She was a psychic who was later revealed to be a fraud.

children.name: pretend
children.definition: to pretend sth as a game, or because you enjoy it: giả đò
examples: pretend (that)
I like to drive around in my brother’s BMW and pretend I’m a rich businessman.
pretend to be
He burst into the room with a toy gun in his hand, pretending to be a gangster.

children.name: make believe
children.definition: to pretend that pleasant things are happening, that you are sb or somewhere you want to be, etc: giả vờ
examples: Right, kids. We don’t have any proper cowboy hats so you’ll have to make believe.
make believe (that)
The two little girls used to make believe that they were princesses.
Let's make believe(that)we're pirates.
make-believe[U noun]
She’s not really a queen -- it’s only make-believe.

children.name: play
children.definition: /playat  if children play or play at sth, they pretend to be a particular type of person or to do a particular thing, as a game : giả vờ đóng vai
examples: When I was young we played at pirates whenever we were on the beach.
When my sister was little, she always wanted to play school.
The children were playing at Batman and Robin.
play doctors and nurses
Did you ever play doctors and nurses when you were small?
play happy families[UK]/play house[US][pretend to be a family]
Come on - let’s go inside and play house!

children.name: an attempt to pretend that sth is true
pretence
children.definition: /pretense  an attempt to pretend that sth is true, especially in order to deceive people: sự giả bộ
examples: pretence of
After my mother left, my father gave up even the pretense of caring for anyone besides himself.
pretence that
The worst thing about liberal academics is the pretence that they are somehow more open-minded than their opponents.
on the pretence that/ of[pretending that it is the reason for what you are doing] giả bộ rằng
Wilson asked Carly out to dinner, on the pretence that he wanted to talk to her about business.
The first time she had called was on the pretense of finding out how Letia was.
make a pretence of doing sth[pretend to do it]
Mr Tellwright made no pretence of concealing his satisfaction.
keep up the pretence[continue pretending]
After two weeks he could keep up the pretence no longer and decided to tell her the truth.

children.name: charade
children.definition: a situation in which people pretend that sth is true and behave as if it were true, especially when everyone really knows that it is not true: trò giả vờ
examples: The trial was just a charade -- the verdict had already been decided.
Simon told Susan that his marriage was a charade, continued only for the sake of the children.

children.name: sham
children.definition: an attempt to deceive people by pretending that sth is true, especially if it is easy for people to see that it is not true: trò vờ vịt
examples: She believed Rodney’s sudden change in attitude was only a sham.
The election was a sham. Officials intimidated peasants into voting for the government candidates, or simply stuffed the ballot boxes.

children.name: front
children.definition: an organization or activity that seems to be legal and ordinary but which is secretly being used for an illegal purpose : trá hình
examples: The club was just a front - Luchese’s real business was drug smuggling and gun running.
front for
The charity has been accused of being a front for anti-government activity.
Several trading companies were set up in the early 1960s to act as frontsformoney-laundering operations.
